description: Next Best Action (NBA) rules engine configuration for AliveTrust living trust management

rules.name: Fund unfunded real estate via deed recording
rules.description: Real property held in the grantor's individual name must be transferred into the trust via a new grant deed to avoid probate. This is typically the highest-value gap in a trust plan.
steps: Obtain current preliminary title report or property profile to confirm current ownership
Prepare a new grant deed transferring property from grantor(s) individually to grantor(s) as trustees of the trust
Have the grant deed notarized by all current owners
File a Preliminary Change of Ownership Report (PCOR) claiming the trust transfer exemption from reassessment
Record the deed with the county recorder's office in the county where the property is located
Obtain a certified copy of the recorded deed for trust records
Notify the mortgage lender of the trust transfer (if applicable)
Update title insurance policy to reflect trust ownership
Upload recording confirmation as evidence in AliveTrust
evidence_required: Recorded grant deed (certified copy)
County recorder confirmation with document number
Filed PCOR form
Updated title insurance policy or endorsement
rules.done_definition: Property deed has been recorded with the county, confirmed by recording number, and title reflects trust ownership.
escalation_conditions: Property has an active mortgage with a lender that claims due-on-sale clause applies
Property is held in joint tenancy with a non-trust party
Property is located outside the trust's state of formation
Property has liens, judgments, or encumbrances requiring resolution
Property is in a community property state with complex ownership history

rules.name: Fix beneficiary mismatch on life insurance policy
rules.description: A life insurance policy names an individual as beneficiary instead of the trust. This can cause proceeds to bypass the trust, defeating estate plan intentions and potentially creating probate or unintended distribution issues.
steps: Review the trust document for specific life insurance distribution provisions
Contact the insurance company to request a beneficiary change form
Determine the correct designation: trust as primary beneficiary, individuals as contingent (or vice versa per attorney guidance)
Complete the beneficiary change form with the exact trust name and date: '[Trust Name] dated [Date]'
Submit the completed form to the insurance company
Obtain written confirmation from the insurer that the beneficiary change has been processed
Upload the confirmation letter or updated beneficiary designation form as evidence
evidence_required: Completed beneficiary change form (copy)
Insurance company confirmation letter showing updated beneficiary
Updated policy declaration page reflecting new beneficiary
rules.done_definition: Insurance company has confirmed in writing that the beneficiary designation has been updated to match the trust plan.
escalation_conditions: Policy is an irrevocable life insurance trust (ILIT) situation requiring separate trust
Policy has been assigned or collaterally assigned to a lender
Community property state implications for beneficiary changes without spouse consent
Policy value exceeds estate tax exemption threshold and may need ILIT planning
Multiple policies with conflicting beneficiary designations

rules.name: Execute missing durable financial power of attorney
rules.description: No durable financial power of attorney (POA) is on file. Without a financial POA, incapacity leaves non-trust assets unmanageable and may require costly court-supervised conservatorship proceedings.
steps: Consult with estate planning attorney about scope of powers to include
Determine who should serve as agent (typically spouse, then adult child)
Draft the durable financial power of attorney with appropriate powers and limitations
Include 'springing' vs 'immediate' effectiveness decision based on grantor preference
Execute the document with proper notarization (California requires notarization for financial POA)
Provide copies to the named agent(s) and successor agent(s)
Consider registering the POA with financial institutions proactively
Store the original in a secure but accessible location
Upload signed and notarized POA scan as evidence
evidence_required: Signed and notarized financial POA document (scan)
Confirmation of delivery to named agent(s)
rules.done_definition: A durable financial power of attorney has been properly executed, notarized, and copies provided to all named agents.
escalation_conditions: Grantor has diminished capacity and may not be able to execute a new POA
Complex financial situation requiring specialized POA powers (business management, real estate transactions, tax filings)
Blended family situation where agent selection is contentious
Grantor owns property or accounts in multiple states

rules.name: Review business operating agreement for trust transfer
rules.description: A business interest (LLC, partnership, or corporation) has unknown transfer status. The operating agreement or bylaws may restrict or prohibit transfer to a trust without member/shareholder consent.
steps: Obtain the current operating agreement (LLC), partnership agreement, or bylaws (corporation)
Review for transfer restriction clauses, anti-assignment provisions, and right-of-first-refusal provisions
Identify consent requirements: do other members/partners need to approve the transfer?
Consult with business attorney on whether trust transfer is permitted or requires amendment
If permitted, prepare an assignment of membership interest (LLC) or stock transfer (corporation) to the trust
If amendment needed, draft and obtain member/partner consent to amend the operating agreement
Execute the transfer document and update the company's records
File any required amendments with the Secretary of State
Obtain a new Schedule K-1 or other documentation reflecting trust ownership
Upload the amended operating agreement and assignment as evidence
evidence_required: Current operating agreement or bylaws (reviewed and annotated)
Member/partner consent to trust transfer (if required)
Assignment of membership interest or stock transfer document
Amended operating agreement (if applicable)
Secretary of State filing confirmation (if required)
rules.done_definition: Business interest has been formally assigned to the trust per the operating agreement, with all required consents obtained and records updated.
escalation_conditions: Operating agreement prohibits trust transfers entirely
Other members refuse to consent to the transfer
Business has buy-sell agreement that conflicts with trust transfer
Transfer could trigger adverse tax consequences (e.g., S-Corp eligibility issues)
Business operates in a regulated industry requiring ownership change approval

rules.name: Record deed for real property transfer
rules.description: A deed has been prepared but not yet recorded, or a property has been identified for transfer and needs a deed prepared and recorded. This is the mechanical step of getting the deed filed with the county recorder.
steps: Prepare the grant deed (or quitclaim deed, depending on situation) with correct legal description
Verify the legal description matches the county assessor's records exactly
Include the trust's full legal name: '[Grantor Name(s)], Trustee(s) of the [Trust Name] dated [Date]'
Have all current titleholders sign and notarize the deed
Prepare and attach the Preliminary Change of Ownership Report (PCOR)
Submit the deed and PCOR to the county recorder with applicable recording fees
Receive the recorded deed with document number and recording date
Order a certified copy of the recorded deed for trust records
Update the trust's asset schedule to reflect the transfer
evidence_required: Recorded grant deed with county document number
PCOR filing confirmation
Certified copy of recorded deed
rules.done_definition: Deed has been recorded with the county recorder and a certified copy with recording number has been obtained and filed in trust records.
escalation_conditions: Legal description discrepancy between deed and county records
Title defects discovered during preparation
Property is in another county or state requiring different procedures
Existing liens must be addressed before transfer

rules.name: Update bank or brokerage account titling to trust
rules.description: A financial account (checking, savings, brokerage, or CD) is held in individual name and should be retitled to the trust to avoid probate and ensure the account passes per trust terms.
steps: Contact the financial institution and request their trust account retitling process and forms
Provide a Certificate of Trust (Probate Code 18100.5) — the institution cannot require the full trust document
Complete the institution's trust account application or retitling form
Update the account title to: '[Grantor Name(s)], Trustee(s) of [Trust Name] dated [Date]'
Verify new account statements reflect trust titling
Update or add beneficiary/TOD designations if applicable
Obtain and upload confirmation letter as evidence
evidence_required: Account retitling confirmation letter from institution
Updated account statement showing trust name
Updated beneficiary designation form (if applicable)
rules.done_definition: Financial institution has confirmed account retitling in writing and the next statement reflects the trust name as account owner.
escalation_conditions: Institution refuses to accept Certificate of Trust and demands full trust document
Account has UTMA/UGMA provisions that complicate trust transfer
Account is a joint account with a non-trust party
CDs have early termination penalties that may be triggered

rules.name: Get Certificate of Trust notarized and distributed
rules.description: A notarized Certificate of Trust allows the trustee to prove their authority to third parties without revealing the full trust document. Essential for funding accounts, recording deeds, and managing trust assets.
steps: Draft the Certificate of Trust per California Probate Code 18100.5 requirements
Include: trust name, date, trustee names, trust powers, trust TIN/SSN, whether trust is revocable, and relevant trust provisions (without detailed distribution terms)
Have all current trustees sign the certificate
Notarize the certificate
Make multiple certified copies for use with financial institutions, title companies, and other third parties
Store the original with the trust document
Upload the notarized certificate as evidence
evidence_required: Signed and notarized Certificate of Trust (scan)
Confirmation of distribution to relevant parties
rules.done_definition: A notarized Certificate of Trust has been executed and multiple certified copies are available for third-party use.
escalation_conditions: Trust has been amended and certificate needs to reflect amendments
Trustee has changed since last certificate was prepared
Out-of-state institution requires additional documentation beyond the certificate

rules.name: Conduct annual trust review
rules.description: An annual review ensures the trust remains current with life changes, asset changes, law changes, and beneficiary circumstances. Recommended at least once per year or after any major life event.
steps: Review trust document for alignment with current wishes and family situation
Verify all assets are still properly titled/funded (run AliveTrust funding audit)
Check beneficiary designations on all non-trust assets (retirement, insurance, POD accounts)
Review trustee and successor trustee selections — are named individuals still willing and able?
Confirm all ancillary documents are current (POA, healthcare directive, pour-over will)
Check for any new assets acquired since last review that need to be funded into the trust
Review for any changes in federal or state law affecting the trust plan
Discuss any life changes: marriage, divorce, birth, death, relocation, disability
Document the review and any recommended changes
Schedule next annual review
evidence_required: Completed annual review checklist (signed and dated)
Updated asset schedule (if changes were made)
Notes on any recommended amendments
rules.done_definition: A comprehensive review of the trust, assets, beneficiaries, and ancillary documents has been completed and documented within the past 12 months.
escalation_conditions: Significant law changes affecting estate tax exemptions or trust rules
Grantor has moved to a different state since trust creation
Marriage, divorce, or death of a beneficiary or trustee
Substantial change in estate value (up or down) affecting tax planning
Trust has not been reviewed in more than 3 years

rules.name: Add successor trustee if missing
rules.description: The trust does not name a successor trustee, or all named successors are no longer able or willing to serve. Without a successor, a court may need to appoint one upon the grantor's death or incapacity.
steps: Identify potential successor trustees: family members, trusted friends, professional fiduciaries, or corporate trustees
Evaluate candidates for willingness, competence, geographic proximity, and impartiality
Discuss the role and responsibilities with the proposed successor(s)
Consider naming both an individual and a corporate/professional trustee as backup
Draft a trust amendment naming the successor trustee(s) with clear succession order
Execute the amendment with proper formalities (notarization recommended)
Provide the successor trustee(s) with a copy of the trust or at minimum a letter explaining their role
Upload the executed amendment as evidence
evidence_required: Executed trust amendment naming successor trustee(s)
Written acceptance or acknowledgment from named successor(s)
rules.done_definition: At least one successor trustee has been named in the trust via a properly executed amendment, and the named successor is aware of and willing to accept the role.
escalation_conditions: No suitable individual successor trustee is available
Family dynamics make successor selection contentious
Estate complexity requires a professional or corporate trustee
Grantor is incapacitated and cannot execute an amendment

rules.name: Get healthcare directive properly witnessed
rules.description: A healthcare directive exists but may not be properly witnessed per state requirements, or is missing entirely. California requires either two witnesses or notarization, with specific witness disqualifications.
steps: Obtain the California statutory advance healthcare directive form (Probate Code 4701)
Review and complete all sections: healthcare agent designation, treatment preferences, organ donation, HIPAA authorization
Arrange for proper witnessing: two adult witnesses, at least one of whom is NOT a healthcare provider, operator of a healthcare facility, or related by blood/marriage/adoption
If the principal is in a skilled nursing facility, one witness must be a patient advocate or ombudsman
Alternative: have the directive notarized instead of witnessed
Distribute copies to: healthcare agent(s), primary care physician, hospital, and close family members
Keep the original in an accessible location (NOT a safe deposit box)
Upload the signed and witnessed directive as evidence
evidence_required: Signed healthcare directive with proper witness signatures or notarization (scan)
Confirmation of delivery to healthcare agent and physician
rules.done_definition: Healthcare directive has been executed with proper California witnessing requirements and distributed to all relevant parties.
escalation_conditions: Principal has limited English proficiency and needs translated documents
Principal is in a skilled nursing facility with special witnessing requirements
Complex medical situation requiring specific treatment instructions
Disagreement among family members about healthcare preferences

rules.name: Verify bank acceptance of power of attorney
rules.description: Even a properly executed POA may be rejected by a financial institution. Proactive registration with key institutions ensures the agent can act without delay when needed.
steps: Compile a list of all financial institutions where the principal holds accounts
Contact each institution to inquire about their POA acceptance process and any institution-specific forms
Submit the POA to each institution for pre-registration (some institutions require their own POA form in addition to the statutory form)
Complete any institution-specific POA acknowledgment forms
Request written confirmation from each institution that the POA is on file and will be honored
Note that California Probate Code 4303 requires financial institutions to accept statutory POAs and provides remedies for unreasonable refusal
Upload acceptance confirmations as evidence for each institution
evidence_required: Written POA acceptance or acknowledgment from each financial institution
Copies of any institution-specific POA forms completed
rules.done_definition: All key financial institutions have acknowledged the POA on file and confirmed they will honor it when presented by the agent.
escalation_conditions: Financial institution refuses to accept the POA
Institution requires its own proprietary POA form that may conflict with trust terms
POA is more than 2 years old and institution questions its currency
Agent is a non-US resident and institution has identification concerns

rules.name: Transfer vehicle title to trust
rules.description: A vehicle is titled in the grantor's individual name and has not been transferred to the trust. While vehicles are lower-priority for trust funding, transferring avoids probate and simplifies successor trustee management.
steps: Obtain the current vehicle title (pink slip) from the lender if financed, or from personal records
Complete California DMV REG 227 (Application for Duplicate or Transfer of Title) transferring ownership to the trust
The new owner should be listed as: '[Grantor Name], Trustee of [Trust Name] dated [Date]'
Submit the completed form, current title, and applicable fees to the DMV
If the vehicle is financed, contact the lienholder first to confirm they allow trust transfer
Receive the new title reflecting trust ownership
Update vehicle insurance to reflect trust as named insured (or add trust as additional insured)
Upload the new title and insurance update as evidence
evidence_required: Updated vehicle title showing trust as owner
DMV transfer confirmation
Updated insurance declaration page
rules.done_definition: California DMV has issued a new title reflecting trust ownership and vehicle insurance has been updated accordingly.
escalation_conditions: Vehicle is financed and lienholder refuses trust transfer
Vehicle is leased rather than owned
Vehicle is a collector/vintage car with special insurance considerations
Multiple vehicles requiring transfer (may consider leaving low-value vehicles outside trust)

rules.name: Review tax implications of trust funding
rules.description: Certain asset transfers into a trust may have tax consequences: property tax reassessment, capital gains recognition, gift tax implications, or retirement account distribution triggers. A tax review ensures no unintended tax liability.
steps: Review all recent and planned asset transfers for tax implications
Real estate: Verify trust transfer qualifies for property tax reassessment exclusion (Proposition 19/13)
Retirement accounts: Confirm these are NOT being retitled (should use beneficiary designations only)
Business interests: Check for potential gift tax or income tax recognition on transfer
Review the trust's grantor trust status for income tax purposes (revocable trusts are generally tax-neutral during grantor's lifetime)
Confirm no assets are being transferred that would trigger capital gains (e.g., installment obligations, foreign assets)
Document the tax review conclusions for each asset category
Consult with CPA or tax advisor if any ambiguous situations arise
evidence_required: Tax review memorandum or checklist (signed by preparer)
CPA or tax advisor confirmation letter (if professional review conducted)
Filed PCOR forms for real estate transfers
rules.done_definition: All recent and planned trust funding transfers have been reviewed for tax implications, with no unaddressed tax issues remaining.
escalation_conditions: Estate value approaches or exceeds federal estate tax exemption ($13.61M for 2024)
Trust holds assets in multiple states with varying tax rules
Transfer of appreciated property that may not qualify for step-up in basis
S-Corporation shares being transferred (trust must qualify as eligible shareholder)
Grantor is a non-US citizen with different estate/gift tax rules

rules.name: Update digital asset access plan
rules.description: Digital assets (online accounts, cryptocurrency, digital files, social media, domain names) are often overlooked in trust planning. Without a digital asset plan, successor trustees may be unable to access or manage these assets.
steps: Create an inventory of all digital assets: email accounts, social media, financial accounts, cryptocurrency wallets, cloud storage, domain names, digital subscriptions, online businesses
For each digital asset, document: account name, URL, username, and how to access (password manager reference, NOT plaintext passwords)
Set up a password manager (e.g., 1Password, Bitwarden) and store the master password securely
Document the location of the master password or recovery key in the trustee instruction letter
Review each platform's legacy/memorialization/inactive account policies
Designate legacy contacts where platforms support it (Google Inactive Account Manager, Facebook Legacy Contact, Apple Legacy Contact)
For cryptocurrency: document wallet types, seed phrase storage location, and recovery procedures
Include digital asset access instructions in the trust's trustee instruction letter
Consider whether a specific provision in the trust or a separate digital asset authorization is needed under California's Revised Uniform Fiduciary Access to Digital Assets Act (RUFADAA)
evidence_required: Digital asset inventory (encrypted or stored in password manager)
Password manager setup confirmation
Legacy contact designations for major platforms
Digital asset access instructions for successor trustee
rules.done_definition: A comprehensive digital asset inventory exists with access instructions for the successor trustee, and legacy contacts have been designated where available.
escalation_conditions: Significant cryptocurrency holdings requiring specialized custody/recovery planning
Digital businesses generating income that require continuity planning
International digital assets subject to foreign laws
Complex two-factor authentication setups that could lock out a successor

rules.name: Create trustee instruction letter
rules.description: A trustee instruction letter (also called a letter of intent or memorandum of wishes) provides practical guidance to the successor trustee beyond what is in the legal trust document. It covers logistics, preferences, and practical matters.
steps: Draft a letter addressed to the successor trustee(s) covering the following topics:
Location of important documents: trust original, will, deeds, insurance policies, tax returns, birth/marriage certificates
List of professional advisors: attorney, CPA, financial advisor, insurance agent — with contact information
Complete list of assets and accounts with institution names, account numbers, and contact information
Digital asset access instructions and password manager information
List of recurring bills, subscriptions, and automatic payments that need to be managed
Funeral and memorial preferences (if not covered elsewhere)
Special instructions for specific beneficiaries (e.g., a child with special needs, a beneficiary with substance abuse issues)
Personal property distribution wishes for items not specifically mentioned in the trust
Any pending legal matters, disputes, or obligations the trustee should be aware of
Store the letter with the trust documents but keep it updatable (not notarized — it is not a legal document)
Upload the letter as evidence and update annually
evidence_required: Completed trustee instruction letter (signed and dated)
Confirmation that successor trustee knows where to find the letter
rules.done_definition: A comprehensive trustee instruction letter has been drafted, signed, and stored with the trust documents, and the successor trustee has been informed of its existence and location.
escalation_conditions: Complex trust with multiple sub-trusts or special needs provisions
Business succession instructions requiring detailed operational guidance
International assets or beneficiaries requiring cross-border instructions
Contentious family dynamics requiring sensitive handling instructions

rules.name: Fix beneficiary mismatch on retirement accounts
rules.description: A retirement account (IRA, 401(k), 403(b)) has a beneficiary designation that does not align with the trust plan. Retirement accounts pass by beneficiary designation, not by trust terms, so mismatches can defeat the estate plan.
steps: Review the trust document for any specific provisions regarding retirement account distribution

Determine the optimal beneficiary designation strategy with tax advisor: naming individuals directly (preferred for stretch IRA benefits) vs. naming the trust (required for certain control provisions)
If naming the trust as beneficiary, verify the trust qualifies as a 'see-through' or 'conduit' trust under IRS regulations to preserve favorable distribution options
Contact the retirement plan administrator to obtain a beneficiary change form
Complete the form with the correct primary and contingent beneficiary designations
If married, obtain spousal consent for non-spouse primary beneficiary (required for most qualified plans)
Submit the completed form and obtain written confirmation
Upload the confirmation as evidence
evidence_required: Updated beneficiary designation form (copy)
Plan administrator confirmation of beneficiary change
Spousal consent form (if applicable)
rules.done_definition: Retirement account beneficiary designations have been updated to align with the trust plan, confirmed in writing by the plan administrator.
escalation_conditions: Significant retirement account balance that could benefit from specialized trust provisions (accumulation trust vs. conduit trust)
SECURE Act implications for non-spouse beneficiaries and the 10-year rule
Community property state spousal rights complications
Qualified plan with restrictive beneficiary designation options
Beneficiary with special needs requiring a special needs trust as beneficiary

rules.name: Upload missing evidence for funded assets
rules.description: Assets are marked as funded but lack supporting evidence (confirmation letters, recorded deeds, retitling confirmations). Evidence is essential for successor trustees and for verifying the trust plan's completeness.
steps: Identify all funded assets that lack uploaded evidence
For each asset, determine what evidence should exist: deed recording, account statement, beneficiary confirmation, title document
Gather the supporting documents from files, institutions, or online accounts
Scan or download digital copies of each document
Upload each evidence item to AliveTrust, linking it to the correct asset
Verify each evidence item matches the asset details (account numbers, property addresses, trust name)
Mark evidence as verified once confirmed
evidence_required: Relevant confirmation documents for each funded asset (varies by asset type)
rules.done_definition: Every funded or partially funded asset has at least one piece of supporting evidence uploaded and verified in the system.
escalation_conditions: Institution no longer exists (merged, closed) and records are unavailable
Asset was funded so long ago that original documentation cannot be located
Evidence reveals a discrepancy (e.g., title shows different name than expected)

rules.name: Execute pour-over will if missing
rules.description: No pour-over will exists to catch assets that are inadvertently left outside the trust at death. Without a pour-over will, unfunded assets pass by intestacy rather than trust terms.
steps: Engage estate planning attorney to draft a pour-over will
The will should direct that all probate assets be transferred ('poured over') into the living trust
Name an executor (personal representative) — typically the same person as successor trustee
Include guardian nominations for minor children if applicable
Execute the will with California formalities: signed by testator in presence of two witnesses who also sign
Do NOT notarize the will (California does not require notarization for wills, and a notarized will is not self-proving in CA)
Consider adding a self-proving affidavit if the will may need to be probated in another state
Store the original will in a secure, known location (NOT a safe deposit box unless someone else has access)
Upload a scan of the executed will as evidence
evidence_required: Executed pour-over will (scan showing signatures and witnesses)
Confirmation of original storage location
rules.done_definition: A pour-over will has been properly executed with two witnesses and stored in a known, accessible location.
escalation_conditions: Grantor has minor children requiring guardian nominations
Grantor has assets in multiple states requiring ancillary probate consideration
Grantor has a prior will that needs to be explicitly revoked
Blended family situation requiring careful coordination between will and trust
